docs.title: Running Docker in VDI Environment
docs.text: In corporate VDI (Virtual Desktop Infrastructure) environments, Docker Desktop may require elevated privileges to run properly.

docs.title: Step 1: Right-click Docker Desktop
docs.text: Right-click the Docker Desktop shortcut and select Run with Administrator Privileges.

docs.title: Step 2: Provide Elevation Reason
docs.text: A Privilege Elevation dialog will appear. Enter a reason (e.g., "Development work") and click Continue.

docs.title: Step 3: Confirmation
docs.text:
You'll see a confirmation that Docker is now running with administrator privileges.

TIP: If Docker fails to start containers or shows permission errors, running with elevated privileges usually resolves these issues in VDI environments.

docs.title: Login to Azure Container Registry
docs.text:
Before pulling images from Azure Container Registry (ACR), you need to authenticate with Azure first.

WARNING: In VDI environments, run these commands in a normal terminal (not elevated). ACR login does not work in terminals started with administrator privileges.

docs.title: Step 1: Login to Azure
docs.text:
az login

Or use device code for remote/VDI sessions:

az login --use-device-code

docs.title: Step 2: Select Subscription
docs.text:
List available subscriptions and select the correct one:

az account list -o table
az account set -s "<subscription-name-or-id>"

docs.title: Step 3: Login to ACR
docs.text: az acr login -n <acr-name>

docs.title: Step 4: Docker Login
docs.text:
docker login <acr-name>.azurecr.io

NOTE: ACR login tokens are valid for 3 hours. Re-run az acr login and docker login if you get authentication errors.

docs.title: Troubleshooting: Docker Login Still Fails
docs.text:
If docker login still doesn't work, edit the Docker config file:

  • Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.docker\config.json
  • macOS/Linux: ~/.docker/config.json

Change credsStore from:

"credsStore": "wincred",

To:

"credsStore": "",

Then retry the docker login command.

docs.title: Custom Install Path (Windows)
docs.text:
Don't double-click the installer. Use command line to specify custom paths.

PowerShellCMD 
# Run as Administrator
cd ~\Downloads
Start-Process -Wait -FilePath ".\Docker Desktop Installer.exe" -ArgumentList "install", "-accept-license", "--installation-dir=D:\Docker", "--wsl-default-data-root=D:\Docker\images"

:: Run as Administrator
cd %USERPROFILE%\Downloads
start /w "" "Docker Desktop Installer.exe" install -accept-license --installation-dir=D:\Docker --wsl-default-data-root=D:\Docker\images

Flags explained:

Flag Purpose -accept-license Auto-accept license agreement --installation-dir=D:\Docker Install Docker app to D:\Docker --wsl-default-data-root=D:\Docker\images Store WSL data & images on D:

NOTE: Without --wsl-default-data-root, images still go to %HOME%\AppData\Local\Docker

docs.title: Clone
docs.text:
SSHHTTPS 
git clone git@github.com:<username>/<repo>.git

NOTE: If you have multiple SSH profiles, replace github.com with your SSH config host (e.g., github_vdi). Check your ~/.ssh/config file.

git clone https://github.com/<username>/<repo>.git

docs.title: Push Existing Local Project to GitHub
docs.text:
If you already have a local project with git init, connect it to GitHub:

SSHHTTPS 
git remote add origin git@github.com:<username>/<repo>.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

NOTE: If you have multiple SSH profiles, replace github.com with your SSH config host (e.g., github_vdi). Check your ~/.ssh/config file.

git remote add origin https://github.com/<username>/<repo>.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

NOTE: Create an empty repository on GitHub first (without README or .gitignore) before pushing.

docs.title: Branch Management
docs.text: Command Description git switch <branch> Switch to an existing branch git switch -c <branch> Create and switch to a new branch git switch - Switch to the previous branch git branch List local branches git branch -a List all branches (local and remote) git branch -d <branch> Delete a branch (safe, checks if merged) git branch -D <branch> Force delete a branch (even if not merged) git branch -m <old> <new> Rename a branch

docs.title: Flags for git switch
docs.text: Flag Description -c Create a new branch and switch to it - Switch to the previously checked out branch --discard-changes Discard local changes when switching

docs.title: Committing
docs.text: Command Description git add . Stage all changes in current directory git add -A Stage all changes (entire repo) git add <file> Stage a specific file git commit -m "message" Commit with a message git status Show working tree status git diff Show unstaged changes

docs.title: One-liner (Add + Commit)
docs.text:
git add -A && git commit -m "Your message here"

Or using PowerShell 5.x (use semicolon):

git add -A; git commit -m "Your message here"

docs.title: Flags for git add
docs.text: Flag Description -A Stage all changes (new, modified, deleted) in entire repo . Stage all changes in current directory and subdirectories -p Interactive staging (choose which hunks to stage) -u Stage only modified and deleted files (not new files)

docs.title: Flags for git commit
docs.text: Flag Description -m "message" Provide commit message inline -a Automatically stage modified files (not new files) -am "message" Combine -a and -m (stage modified + commit) --amend Modify the last commit

docs.title: Merging
docs.text: Command Description git merge <branch> Merge a branch into current branch git merge --abort Cancel a merge in progress

docs.title: Flags for git merge
docs.text: Flag Description --no-ff Create a merge commit even for fast-forward --abort Abort the current merge operation --squash Squash all commits into one (no auto-commit)

docs.title: Remote Operations
docs.text: Command Description git pull origin <branch> Fetch and merge from remote git push origin <branch> Push branch to remote git push -u origin <branch> Push and set upstream tracking git push origin --delete <branch> Delete a remote branch

docs.title: Flags for git push
docs.text: Flag Description -u Set upstream tracking for the branch --delete Delete a branch on the remote

docs.title: Flags for git pull
docs.text: Flag Description --rebase Rebase instead of merge when pulling

docs.title: Stash
docs.text: Command Description git stash Temporarily save uncommitted changes git stash pop Restore stashed changes and remove from stash git stash list Show all stashed changes git stash drop Delete most recent stash

docs.title: Undo
docs.text: Command Description git restore <file> Discard changes in a file (back to last commit) git restore --staged <file> Unstage a file (keeps changes in working directory) git reset --soft HEAD~1 Undo last commit but keep changes staged git reset --hard HEAD~1 Undo last commit and discard all changes git commit --amend Edit the last commit message or add forgotten files

docs.title: Add SSH Key to GitHub
docs.text:
1. Go to GitHub SSH Settings
  2. Click New SSH key
  3. Give it a title (e.g., "Work Laptop")
  4. Paste your public key
  5. Click Add SSH key

NOTE: See GitHub's official guide: Adding a new SSH key to your GitHub account

docs.title: Why Port 443?
docs.text:
Many corporate firewalls block port 22 (default SSH port). GitHub allows SSH connections over port 443 (HTTPS port) which is usually open.

macOS / LinuxWindows

Edit ~/.ssh/config:

Host github.com
    HostName ssh.github.com
    Port 443
    User git
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Edit C:\Users\<username>\.ssh\config:

Host github.com
    HostName ssh.github.com
    Port 443
    User git
    IdentityFile C:\Users\<username>\.ssh\id_ed25519

docs.title: Test Connection
docs.text:
ssh -T git@github.com

Expected output:

Hi username! You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.

docs.title: Multiple Git Profiles
docs.text: If you have multiple GitHub accounts (e.g., personal and work), you can configure separate SSH keys and profiles.

docs.title: Step 1: Generate Separate Keys
docs.text:
# Personal account
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "personal@email.com" -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_personal

# Work account
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "work@company.com" -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_work

docs.title: Step 2: Add Keys to SSH Agent
docs.text:
macOS / LinuxWindows 
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_personal
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_work

ssh-add $env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_ed25519_personal
ssh-add $env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_ed25519_work

docs.title: Step 3: Configure SSH Config
docs.text:
Edit ~/.ssh/config (or C:\Users\<username>\.ssh\config on Windows):

# Personal GitHub
Host github.com
    HostName ssh.github.com
    Port 443
    User git
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_personal

# Work GitHub (use custom host alias)
Host github_work
    HostName ssh.github.com
    Port 443
    User git
    IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519_work

docs.title: Step 4: Add Keys to GitHub Accounts
docs.text:
Add each public key to its respective GitHub account:

  • Personal: Add id_ed25519_personal.pub to your personal GitHub
  • Work: Add id_ed25519_work.pub to your work GitHub

docs.title: Step 5: Clone Using Profile
docs.text:
# Personal (default)
git clone git@github.com:personal-user/repo.git

# Work (use custom host)
git clone git@github_work:work-org/repo.git

docs.title: Step 6: Configure Git User Per Repository
docs.text:
After cloning, set the correct user for each repo:

cd /path/to/work/repo
git config user.name "Your Work Name"
git config user.email "work@company.com"

TIP: For automatic user config based on folder, see Conditional Git Config.

docs.title: Permission denied (publickey)
docs.text:
# Check which key is being used
ssh -vT git@github.com

# Verify key is added to agent
ssh-add -l

docs.title: Connection timed out
docs.text: Your firewall may be blocking port 22. Use port 443 config above.

docs.title: Multiple profiles not working
docs.text:
Make sure you're using the correct host alias in your git remote:

# Check current remote
git remote -v

# Update to use correct profile
git remote set-url origin git@github_work:org/repo.git

docs.title: Branch Structure
docs.text:
main
  └── integration
        ├── feature/xyz
        ├── feature/abc
        └── fix/bug-123
Branch Purpose main Production-ready code (stable, tested) integration Staging area where features are merged and tested feature/* Individual work branches for new features fix/* Bug fix branches

docs.title: 1. Start New Work
docs.text:
git switch integration
git pull origin integration
git switch -c feature/my-feature

docs.title: 2. Develop and Commit
docs.text:
git add .
git commit -m "Add feature description"

docs.title: 3. Merge to Integration
docs.text:
git switch integration
git pull origin integration
git merge feature/my-feature
git push origin integration

docs.title: 4. Test
docs.text: docker-compose up --build

docs.title: 5. Release to Production
docs.text:
git switch main
git pull origin main
git merge integration
git push origin main

docs.title: 6. Cleanup
docs.text: git branch -d feature/my-feature

docs.title: Visual Workflow
docs.text:
feature/xyz → integration → main
     ↓             ↓          ↓
  develop        test     production

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Never work directly on main — always go through integration
  2. Never push to main without testing on integration first
  3. Keep features small and focused — easier to review and merge
  4. Merge early, merge often — small merges are easier than large ones
  5. Pull before merge — always update your branch before merging
  6. Update long-running feature branches — merge integration into your feature branch regularly

docs.title: Handling Multiple Features
docs.text:
If you need to pause a feature:

# Save current work
git add .
git commit -m "WIP: feature progress"

# Switch to integration, start new feature
git switch integration
git pull origin integration
git switch -c feature/urgent-fix

# When done, go back to original feature
git switch feature/my-feature
git merge integration

docs.title: Resolving Merge Conflicts
docs.text:
When conflicts occur:

  1. Open the conflicted file
  2. Look for conflict markers: 
    <<<<<<< HEAD
(your branch content)
=======
(incoming branch content)
>>>>>>> branch-name
  3. Edit to keep desired content
  4. Delete the markers (<<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>>)
  5. Save and commit: 
    git add .
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict"

docs.title: Modes
docs.text: Key Mode Description i Insert Start editing text Esc Normal Stop editing, navigate : Command Run commands (save, quit)

docs.title: Navigation (Normal mode)
docs.text: Key Action h j k l Left, Down, Up, Right gg Go to top of file G Go to bottom of file 0 Go to start of line $ Go to end of line w Jump forward one word b Jump backward one word /text Search for "text" n Next search result

docs.title: Editing (Normal mode)
docs.text: Key Action i Insert before cursor a Insert after cursor o New line below and insert O New line above and insert x Delete character dd Delete entire line u Undo Ctrl+r Redo

docs.title: Save and Quit (Normal mode)
docs.text: Command Action :w Save :q Quit :wq Save and quit :q! Quit without saving ZZ Save and quit (shortcut)

docs.title: Quick Conflict Resolution Workflow
docs.text:
1. Press /<<< then Enter to find conflict markers
  2. Press dd to delete the marker line
  3. Navigate with j and k to review content
  4. Delete unwanted lines with dd
  5. Delete remaining markers (=======, >>>>>>>)
  6. Press :wq to save and exit

docs.title: Custom Install Directory (C:\Install\Programs)
docs.text:
To install scoop packages to a custom directory instead of ~\scoop\apps\:

One-time Setup (Run as Administrator):

# 1. Set the global install path environment variable
$env:SCOOP_GLOBAL = 'C:\Install\Programs'
[Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable('SCOOP_GLOBAL', $env:SCOOP_GLOBAL, 'Machine')

# 2. Restart terminal to apply changes

Install Packages Globally:

# Use -g flag to install to global directory
scoop install make -g

Verify Installation:

# Check install location
scoop which make

# Test
make --version

NOTE: Global installs (-g) go to C:\Install\Programs. Regular installs go to ~\scoop\apps\. PATH is automatically updated by scoop.

docs.title: Windows Terminal + PowerShell Setup
docs.text: When group policy blocks profile.ps1 execution, configure starship directly in Windows Terminal settings.

docs.title: Terminal Settings
docs.text:
Open Windows Terminal → Settings → Profiles → PowerShell → Command line:

pwsh.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -NoExit -Command "Invoke-Expression (&starship init powershell)"

Or for Windows PowerShell (not pwsh):

powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -NoExit -Command "Invoke-Expression (&starship init powershell)"

docs.title: settings.json
docs.text:
Open settings.json (Ctrl+Shift+,) and edit the PowerShell profile:

{
    "profiles": {
        "list": [
            {
                "name": "PowerShell",
                "commandline": "pwsh.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -NoExit -Command \"Invoke-Expression (&starship init powershell)\"",
                "font": {
                    "face": "JetBrainsMono Nerd Font"
                }
            }
        ]
    }
}

Flags explained:

Flag Purpose -ExecutionPolicy Bypass Ignores group policy restriction -NoExit Keeps terminal open after command -Command "..." Runs starship init on startup
